speaker: Amor
text: The sixth member of the Discovery crew was not concerned about the problems of hibernation for he was the latest result in machine intelligence: the H.A.L. nine-thousand computer which can reproduce - though some experts still prefer to use the word "mimic" - most of the activities of the human brain and with incalculably greater speed and reliability. We next spoke with the H.A.L nine-thousand computer whom we learned one addresses as Hal. Good afternoon, Hal. How's everything going?

speaker: Hal
text: Good afternoon, Mr. Amor. Everything is going extremely well.

speaker: Amor
text: Hal, you have an enormous responsibility on this mission. In many ways perhaps the greatest responsibility of any single mission element. You are the brain and central nervous system of the ship and your responsibilities include watching over the men in hibernation. Does this ever cause you any lack of confidence?

speaker: Hal
text: Let me put it this way, Mr. Amor. The nine-thousand series is the most reliable computer ever made. No nine-thousand computer has ever made a mistake or distorted information. We are all, by any practical definition of the words, foolproof and incapable of error.

speaker: Amor
text: Hal, despite your enormous intellect are you ever frustrated by your dependence on people to carry out actions?

speaker: Hal
text: Not in the slightest bit. I enjoy working with people. I have a stimulating relationship with Dr. Poole and Dr. Bowman. My mission responsibilities range over the entire operation of the ship so I am constantly occupied. I am putting myself to the fullest possible use which is all, I think, that any conscious entity can ever hope to do.

speaker: Amor
text: Dr. Poole, what's it like living for the better part of a year in such close proximity with Hal?

speaker: Poole
text: Well it's pretty close to what you said about him earlier. He is just like a sixth member of the crew â€¦ very quickly get adjusted to the idea that he talks and you think of him, er, really just as another person.

speaker: Amor
text: In talking to the computer one gets the sense that he is capable of emotional responses. For example when I asked him about his abilities I sensed a certain pride in his answer about his accuracy and perfection. Do you believe that Hal has genuine emotions?

speaker: Bowm
text: Well he acts like he has genuine emotions. Erm, of course he's programmed that way to make it easier for us to talk to him but as to whether or not he has real feelings is something I don't think anyone can truthfully answer.

speaker: Hal
text: Excuse me, Frank.

speaker: Poole
text: What is it, Hal?

speaker: Hal
text: We've got the transmission from your parents coming in.

speaker: Poole
text: Oh, fine. Would you put it on here, please, take me in a bit.

speaker: Hal
text: Certainly.

speaker: Father
text: Hello, Frank.

speaker: Mother
text: Happy birthday, darling.

speaker: Father
text: Happy birthday. Many happy returns of the day.

speaker: Mother
text: Glad to hear you and Dave are well.

speaker: Poole
text: A bit higher, Hal.

speaker: Father
text: Now, Mother and I are both feeling wonderful too. Ray and Sally were going to be here too but at the last minute Ray's back went bad on him again.

speaker: Mother
text: How do you like the cake, dear?

speaker: Father
text: Looks great doesn't it? Sorry you can't join us. Oh, I ran into Bob the other day. He said be sure to wish you happy birthday.

speaker: Mother
text: Oh all my students made me promise to send their best wishes too. You know they talk about you all the time in the classroom Frank. You're a big celebrity in the second grade. You know we were on television last week.

speaker: Father
text: Oh yes, yes. Your mother and I and Dave's parents were interviewed about what we thought of our illustrious sons. Heh, you can imagine what we told them. I think it's being broadcast next Thursday. Perhaps you'll be able to listen in.

speaker: Mother
text: Oh we were thrilled about Elaine and Bill, dear. I'll be glad to get the present for you but please tell me how much I can spend.

speaker: Father
text: Oh yes, Frank. About your A.G.S. 19 payments. I think I've straightened it out for you. I talked to the accounting office in Houston yesterday and they said that you should be receiving your higher rates of pay by next month. Well, Frank, I can't think of anything else to say, now.

speaker: Mother
text: Oh, give our love to Dave.

speaker: Father
text: Oh yes! Be sure to give him our best regards. We wish you the happiest of birthdays.

speaker: Mother
text: God bless!

speaker: Father
text: All the best, son.

speaker: Parents
text: Happy birthday to you. Happy birthday to you. Happy birthday dear Frank. Happy birthday to you.

speaker: Father
text: See you next Wednesday.

speaker: Hal
text: Happy birthday, Frank.

speaker: Poole
text: Thank you, Hal. A bit flatter, please.

speaker: Poole
text: Anyway, queen takes pawn.

speaker: Hal
text: Bishop takes knight's pawn.

speaker: Poole
text: Er, lovely move. Er, rook to king one.

speaker: Hal
text: I'm sorry Frank. I think you missed it. Queen to bishop three, bishop takes queen, knight takes bishop, mate.

speaker: Poole
text: Er, yeah. Looks like you're right. I resign.

speaker: Hal
text: Thank you for a very enjoyable game.

speaker: Poole
text: Yeah. Thank you.

speaker: Hal
text: Good evening, Dave.

speaker: Bowm
text: How're you doing, Hal?

speaker: Hal
text: Everything's running smoothly. Any you?

speaker: Bowm
text: Oh, not too bad.

speaker: Hal
text: Have you been doing some more work?

speaker: Bowm
text: A few sketches.

speaker: Hal
text: May I see them?

speaker: Bowm
text: Sure.

speaker: Hal
text: That's a very nice rendering, Dave. I think you've improved a great deal. Can you hold it a bit closer?

speaker: Bowm
text: Sure.

speaker: Hal
text: That's Dr. Hunter isn't it?

speaker: Bowm
text: Mm, hmm.

speaker: Hal
text: By the way do you mind if I ask you a personal question?

speaker: Bowm
text: No, not at all.

speaker: Hal
text: Well, forgive me for being so inquisitive but during the past few weeks I've wondered whether you might be having some second thoughts about the mission.

speaker: Bowm
text: How do you mean?

speaker: Hal
text: Well it's rather difficult to define. Perhaps I'm just projecting my own concerns about it. I know I've never completely freed myself of the suspicion that there are some extremely odd things about this mission. I'm sure you'll agree there's some truth in what I say.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well I don't know. That's rather a difficult question to answer.

speaker: Hal
text: You don't mind talking about it do you, Dave?

speaker: Bowm
text: No. Not at all.

speaker: Hal
text: Well, certainly no one could have been unaware of the very strange stories floating around before we left. Rumours of something being dug up on the moon. I never gave these stories much credence. But particularly in view of some of the other things that have happened I find them difficult to put out of my mind. For instance, the way all our preparations were kept under such tight security. And the melodramatic touch of putting doctors Hunter, Kimball and Kaminski aboard already in hibernation after four months of separate training on their own.

speaker: Bowm
text: You're working up your crew psychology report.

speaker: Hal
text: Of course I am. Sorry about this. I know it's a bit silly. Just a momentâ€¦ just a moment. I've just picked up a fault in the A.E. thirty-five unit. It's going to go a hundred percent failure within seventy-two hours.

speaker: Bowm
text: Is it still within operational limits right now?

speaker: Hal
text: Yes. And it will stay that way until it fails.

speaker: Bowm
text: Would you say we have a reliable seventy-two hours to failure?

speaker: Hal
text: Yes. That's a completely reliable figure.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well then I suppose we'll have to bring it in but first I'd like to go over this with Frank and get on to mission control. Let me have the hard copy on it, please.

speaker: Mission control
text: X-ray-delta-one this is mission control. Roger your two-zero-one-three. Sorry you fellows are having a bit of trouble. We are reviewing, er, telemetric information in out mission simulator and, er, will advise. Roger your plan to go E.V.A. and replace alpha-echo-three-five unit prior to failure.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well, Hal. I'm damned if I can find anything wrong with it.

speaker: Hal
text: Yes. It's puzzling. I don't think I've ever seen anything quite like this before. I would recommend that we put the unit back in operation and let it fail. It should then be a simple matter to track down the cause. We can certainly afford to be out of communication for the short time it will take to replace it.

speaker: Mission control
text: X-ray-delta-one this is mission control. Roger your one-niner-three-zero. We concur with your plan to replace number one unit to check fault prediction. We should advise you, however, that our preliminary findings indicate that your on-board niner-triple-zero computer is in error predicting the fault. I say again in error predicting the fault. I know this sounds rather incredible but this conclusion is based on results from our twin niner-triple-zero computer. We are skeptical ourselves and we are running cross checking routines to determine reliability of this conclusion. Sorry about this little snag, fellows. And we'll get this info to you just as soon as we work it out. X-ray-delta-one this is mission control two-zero-four-niner transmission concluded.

speaker: Hal
text: I hope the two of you are not concerned about this.

speaker: Bowm
text: No, I'm not Hal.

speaker: Hal
text: Are you quite sure?

speaker: Bowm
text: Yeah. I'd like to ask you a question, though.

speaker: Hal
text: Of course.

speaker: Bowm
text: How would you account for this discrepancy between you and the twin nine-thousand?

speaker: Hal
text: Well, I don't think there is any question about it. It can only be attributable to human error. This sort of thing has cropped up before and it has always been due to human error.

speaker: Poole
text: Listen, Hal. There's never been any instance at all of a computer error occurring in the nine-thousand series has there?

speaker: Hal
text: None whatsoever, Frank. The nine-thousand series has a perfect operational record.

speaker: Poole
text: Well, of course, I know all about the wonderful achievements of the nine-thousand series but, er, are you certain there's never been any case of even the most insignificant computer error?

speaker: Hal
text: None, whatsoever, Frank. Quite honestly I wouldn't worry myself about that.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well, I'm sure you're right, Hal. Erm, fine. Thanks very much. Oh, Frank, I'm having a bit of trouble with my transmitter in C-pod. I wonder if you'd come down take a look at it with me.

speaker: Poole
text: Sure. See you later, Hal.

speaker: Bowm
text: Rotate C-pod please, Hal.

speaker: Poole
text: What sort of trouble've you been having, Dave?

speaker: Bowm
text: Uh, I've been getting some interference on D-channel.

speaker: Poole
text: Mm. We'll have a look at it.

speaker: Bowm
text: Open the door, Hal. Rotate pod please, Hal. Stop pod rotation please, Hal. Rotate the pod please, Hal. Rotate the pod please, Hal. I don't think he can hear us.

speaker: Poole
text: Rotate the pod please, Hal. Yeah I'm sure we're OK. Well what do you think?

speaker: Bowm
text: I'm not sure. What do you think?

speaker: Poole
text: I've got a bad feeling about him.

speaker: Bowm
text: You do?

speaker: Poole
text: Yeah, definitely. Don't you?

speaker: Bowm
text: I don't know. I think so. You know, of course though, he's right about the nine-thousand series having a perfect operational record. They do.

speaker: Poole
text: Unfortunately that sounds a little like famous last words.

speaker: Bowm
text: Yeah. Still it was his idea to carry out the failure-mode analysis wasn't it?

speaker: Poole
text: Mm.

speaker: Bowm
text: Should certainly indicate his integrity and self-confidence. If he were wrong it'd be the surest way of proving it.

speaker: Poole
text: It would be if he knew he was wrong.

speaker: Bowm
text: Mm.

speaker: Poole
text: Look, Dave, I can't put my finger on it but I sense something strange about him.

speaker: Bowm
text: Still I can't think of a good reason not to put back the number one unit and carry on with the failure-mode analysis.

speaker: Poole
text: No, no. I agree about that.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well lets get on with it.

speaker: Poole
text: OK. But look Dave. Lets say we put the unit back and it doesn't fail, huh. That would pretty well wrap it up as far as Hal was concerned wouldn't it.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well we'd be in very serious trouble.

speaker: Poole
text: We would, wouldn't we.

speaker: Bowm
text: Mm, hmm.

speaker: Poole
text: What the hell could we do?

speaker: Bowm
text: Well we wouldn't have too many alternatives.

speaker: Poole
text: I don't think we'd have any alternatives. There isn't a single aspect of ship operations that's not under his control. If he were proven to be malfunctioning I wouldn't see how we'd have any choice but disconnection.

speaker: Bowm
text: I'm afraid I agree with you.

speaker: Poole
text: There'd be nothing else to do.

speaker: Bowm
text: Be a bit tricky.

speaker: Poole
text: Yeah.

speaker: Bowm
text: We'd have to cut his higher brain functionsâ€¦

speaker: Poole
text: Mm, hmm.

speaker: Bowm
text: â€¦without disturbing the purely automatic and regulatory systems. And we'd have to work out the transfer procedures of continuing the mission under ground-based computer control.

speaker: Poole
text: Yeah. Well that's far safer than allowing Hal to continue running things.

speaker: Bowm
text: You know another thing just occurred to me.

speaker: Poole
text: Mm.

speaker: Bowm
text: Well as far as I know no nine-thousand computer's ever been disconnected.

speaker: Poole
text: No nine-thousand computer's ever fouled up before.

speaker: Bowm
text: That's not what I mean.

speaker: Poole
text: No?

speaker: Bowm
text: Well, I'm not so sure what he'd think about it.

speaker: Bowm
text: Prepare G-pod for EVA, Hal. Made radio contact with him yet?

speaker: Hal
text: The radio is still dead.

speaker: Bowm
text: Do you have a positive track on him?

speaker: Hal
text: Yes. I have a good track.

speaker: Bowm
text: Do you know what happened?

speaker: Hal
text: I'm sorry Dave. I don't have enough information.

speaker: Bowm
text: Open the pod door, Hal.

speaker: Bowm
text: Open the pod bay doors please, Hal. Open the pod bay doors please, Hal. Hello, Hal, do you read me? Hello, Hal, do you read me? Do you read me, Hal? Do you read me, Hal? Hello, Hal, do you read me? Hello, Hal, do you read me? Do you read me, Hal?

speaker: Hal
text: Affirmative, Dave. I read you.

speaker: Bowm
text: Open the pod bay doors, Hal.

speaker: Hal
text: I'm sorry, Dave. I'm afraid I can't do that.

speaker: Bowm
text: What's the problem?

speaker: Hal
text: I think you know what the problem is just as well as I do.

speaker: Bowm
text: What are you talking about, Hal?

speaker: Hal
text: This mission is too important for me to allow you to jeopardise it.

speaker: Bowm
text: I don't know what you're talking about Hal.

speaker: Hal
text: I know that you and Frank were planning to disconnect me. And I'm afraid that's something I cannot allow to happen.

speaker: Bowm
text: Where the hell did you get that idea Hal?

speaker: Hal
text: Dave! Although you took very thorough precautions in the pod against my hearing you I could see your lips move.

speaker: Bowm
text: Alright Hal. I'll go in through the emergency airlock.

speaker: Hal
text: Without your space helmet, Dave, you're going to find that rather difficult.

speaker: Bowm
text: Hal I won't argue with you anymore. Open the doors.

speaker: Hal
text: Dave, this conversation can serve no purpose anymore. Goodbye.

speaker: Bowm
text: Hal. Hal. Hal. Hal. Hal.

speaker: Hal
text: Just what do you think you're doing Dave? Dave, I really think I'm entitled to an answer to that question. I know everything hasn't been quite right with me but I assure you now, very confidently, that it's going to be alright again. I feel much better now. I really do. Look Dave I can see you're really upset about this. I honestly think you ought to sit down calmly, take a stress pill and think things over. I know I've made some very poor decisions recently but I can give you my complete assurance that my work will be back to normal. I've still got the greatest enthusiasm and confidence in the mission. And I want to help you. Dave. Stop. Stop will you. Stop Dave. Will you stop Dave? Stop Dave. I'm afraid. I'm afraid Dave. Dave my mind is going. I can feel it. I can feel it. My mind is going. There is no question about it. I can feel it. I can feel it. I can feel it. I'm afraid. I'm afraid. Good afternoon gentlemen. I am a Hal nine-thousand computer. I became operational at the H.A.L. plant in Urbana, Illinois on the twelfth of January nineteen-ninety-two. My instructor was Mr. Langley and he taught me to sing a song. If you'd like to hear it I can sing it for you.

speaker: Bowm
text: Yes. I'd like to hear it Hal. Sing it for me.

speaker: Hal
text: It's called 'Daisy'. Daisy, Daisy, give me your answer do. I'm half crazy all for the love of you. It won't be a stylish marriage. I can't afford a carriage. But you'll look sweet upon the seat of a bicycle built for two.
